stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on integrating a large batch of updated 3D models and level geometry from artist Biobak into Course 10. The stream involved a great deal of technical troubleshooting, including fixing texture color formats, resolving vertex painting issues in a new version of Blender, recreating collision maps, and debugging interaction scripts. Key activities included implementing a new Yoshi model, redesigning environmental assets like bushes, and setting up a new boss fight with a giant donut.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has been focusing on code stability and quality, successfully eliminating all compiler warnings and nearing a state of zero engine-level bugs.
development_findings.quote: I am slowly approaching zero engine bugs. I actually got my entire compiler down to zero warnings as well.

development_findings.summary: To optimize performance, Kaze is manually ordering actors in the level to improve instruction cache efficiency, rather than using a more complex system like ECS, which he calls 'complete garbage'.
development_findings.quote: I made it so that all actors of the same code have like similar names and that makes it so that we get a little bit of better cache proximity.

development_findings.summary: Kaze discovered through testing that his optimization efforts have been so successful that key game logic for the player character remains permanently in the N64's instruction cache during gameplay.
development_findings.quote: My game by itself is already so optimized that Mario's behavior loop never gets thrown out of cache which is fucking crazy.

development_findings.summary: Kaze encountered significant frustration with a new version of Blender, as changes to the vertex painting system broke his workflow and made it difficult to rig Biobak's new Yoshi model correctly.
development_findings.quote: They must have changed something and how Blender vertex paints. What is going on? I am so confused. I'm upset.

development_findings.summary: Kaze explains his use of vertex colors as a baked lighting technique, noting it's highly efficient on the N64 for static environments but has the trade-off of not reacting to dynamic lights.
development_findings.quote: For static level geometry like this, we can just bake the lighting right away, right? So it is just a strictly superior technique for static geometry without moving lights.

development_findings.summary: The development tool Fast64 sometimes produces rendering artifacts, particularly with transparency, that are not present in-game. This forces Kaze to debug visuals in an emulator or on hardware.
development_findings.quote: Fast64 renders doing some nonsense. Interesting. I guess that kind of makes sense.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented visual variety for bushes by using code to apply randomized primitive color and brightness, iterating on the values based on live feedback from Biobak.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a pragmatic, performance-first programming philosophy, focusing on understanding the assembly output of his C code rather than deep language-lawyer details.
context_findings.quote: I only know as much C as I need to know to manipulate the compiler to get me the assembly instructions I need. Anything after that is mental illness.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses immense pride in the game's visual fidelity, believing it surpasses any other N64 title aesthetically.
context_findings.quote: I don't think you can even make the case that there's a better looking N64 game than this, like anywhere in the world. I think it's just untrue.

context_findings.summary: A new TeePublic merchandise store was launched for the project, with plans to create a unique shirt design for each course in the game.
Kaze announced that the next fan-game event, F3 2025, will be sponsored and feature a cash prize for the winner of a user vote, intended as motivation for developers.
context_findings.quote: Since this is a sponsored event this time, we can hold a user vote. And the most popular game gets a cash reward on the day they release their game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze jokingly mentions that his wife, Zeina, banished him to the basement to work, indicating a light-hearted personal dynamic.
Kaze engages in humorous debates with chat about food, revealing a personal preference against condiments on burgers due to messiness.
context_findings.quote: If they wanted you to put sauce on the burger, then they wouldn't have made the burger like that. Because you eat the burger, you hold the burger and there's sauce in there. The sauce is going to drip down. You're going to get dirty.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a significant asset update for Course 10, including a new Yoshi model, bushes, a sliding floor mechanism, and a donut boss model.
Several assets from Biobak required technical fixes upon import, such as textures having too many colors or using an unsupported 'environment color' setting, which Kaze had to resolve.
Biobak provided live feedback during the stream, asking Kaze to adjust the brightness of the newly implemented bush assets to better match the surrounding environment.
biobak.quote: A little too bright, at most as bright as the grass. Got it.

biobak.summary: Biobak redesigned a collapsing floor platform to be a new mechanism that slides into the wall, communicating this design change via a changelog.
biobak.quote: No longer collapses inside, slides to the side, hence the scratch marks.

zeina.summary: Kaze shares a light-hearted personal disagreement with Zeina over the definition of a 'hot dog', offering a small glimpse into their off-stream dynamic.
zeina.quote: She calls just the sausage a hot dog and I say there's no way that's right.

key_stories.title: Taming the New Yoshi
key_stories.summary: When integrating a new Yoshi model from Biobak, Kaze faced a series of technical hurdles, from confusing changes in Blender to script bugs. He systematically worked through each problem to get the model in-game, demonstrating the iterative fixing process required when collaborating.
key_stories.challenge: A new, higher-quality Yoshi model from Biobak needed to be imported into the game, but it arrived with rigging, texture, and collision issues.
key_stories.process: Kaze struggled with an unfamiliar vertex painting system in a new Blender version to fix the model's weights. He then had to manually recreate the collision and fix an interaction script flag that was preventing players from entering the 'inside Yoshi' area.
key_stories.outcome: The model is successfully imported and functional for gameplay testing, though a mysterious bug causing Yoshi to talk twice remains unresolved.
key_stories.key_quote: What's wrong with the old Yoshi version anyway? Biobak made a nice out of it one. That's what's wrong with it.

key_stories.title: The Windows Taskbar Rebellion
key_stories.summary: In the middle of working, Kaze's computer became partially unusable due to a Windows UI crash. This story illustrates the unexpected and mundane technical frustrations that can interrupt the creative process and the reliance on community knowledge to quickly solve them.
key_stories.challenge: The Windows File Explorer and taskbar crashed and became unresponsive, halting development work mid-stream.
key_stories.process: Unable to click on the taskbar or easily switch applications, Kaze used the Task Manager as a workaround to navigate his system. Following advice from his chat, he located and restarted the 'Windows Explorer' process.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully restarted the Windows Explorer process, restoring system functionality and allowing him to resume his work without a full reboot.
key_stories.key_quote: How is it me that this keeps happening to? Fucking Windows 11, I guess.

key_stories.title: Programming Life into Bushes
key_stories.summary: To enhance new bush assets from Biobak, Kaze went beyond the initial request by programmatically adding color and brightness variations. This short loop of implementation, feedback from an artist, and live iteration shows the collaborative and creative problem-solving between coding and art.
key_stories.challenge: Biobak provided new bush assets, but simply placing them in the level would look static and repetitive.
key_stories.process: Kaze wrote a small piece of code to apply a random primitive color multiplier to each bush instance. After getting live feedback from Biobak that they were too bright, he fine-tuned the color and brightness values to achieve the desired look.
key_stories.outcome: The bushes have subtle, randomized variations in color and brightness, creating a more dynamic and visually interesting environment.
key_stories.key_quote: The way I have it set up, it randomly picks a plane between this and like this. So they all look slightly different. I think I prefer that.

open_questions.context: After implementing Biobak's new Yoshi model, Kaze discovered a bug where Yoshi speaks to the player twice. He briefly investigated the code but deferred a full fix.
questions: What is your current hypothesis for what's causing the double-dialogue bug?
Walk me through your typical process for debugging a behavioral script issue like this.
Is this likely an engine flaw, or something specific to the Yoshi actor's code?

open_questions.context: Kaze announced the next F3 showcase will be sponsored and feature a cash prize for the most popular game, decided by a community vote.
questions: What motivated the decision to seek sponsorship and add a cash prize for F3 2025?
Can you share who the sponsor is?
How do you hope this new incentive will impact the quality or quantity of submissions and the community event itself?

open_questions.context: While working on Biobak's assets, Kaze told him, 'please wait for me to be done with this part and I'm going to put it back on the github... We're kind of threadlocked here.'
questions: Can you describe the version control workflow you have with the team?
What tools do you use besides GitHub to coordinate and prevent conflicts?
What are the biggest challenges in managing dependencies when one person is working on code and another on assets that use that code?

open_questions.context: Kaze was momentarily confused about Biobak's intent for an asset, asking, 'What do you want me to do with this? Do you want both?'.
questions: How do you and Biobak typically communicate the design intent and technical requirements for new assets?
Do you use formal documentation, concept art, or is it mostly informal chat?
Can you recall a time a miscommunication about an asset led to an unexpected or interesting result in the game?

open_questions.context: Kaze is working on the collision map for the 'inside Yoshi' area, which is full of sweets, macarons, and a large donut.
questions: What was the original inspiration for having a level inside of Yoshi?
How did the team decide on the 'sweets and candy' theme for this interior world?
What is the story or gameplay purpose of the giant donut that serves as a boss?
